76.61.text: and Guy Davenport, and experimental fiction writers such as Steve Katz,

97.98.text: a room reserved for personal libraries and other special book collections

102.58.text: that are not dispersed among our general rare book holdings.

106.11.text: The Wallace library now resides just next door to the personal

109.27.text: libraries of James Joyce, Ezra Pound, and Evelyn Waugh.

114.15.text: Just two years after Wallace’s tragic death,

117.55.text: it is bittersweet to list the company that his books and papers now keep,

122.38.text: and to see his works fully cataloged and ready for scholars and students to view.

128.28.text: Wallace was born at least a decade later than any other writer whose archive

132.25.text: is held here at the Ransom Center.

134.87.text: But there is no question that his works have already made a significant

138.26.text: impact upon the American literary scene,

141.45.text: and I cannot think of a better writer to serve as the foundation

145.18.text: for our next generation of collecting.

148.66.text: Since we announced the acquisition earlier this year,

151.53.text: the response we have seen from scholars, students,

154.14.text: and fans has been overwhelmingly positive.

159.71.text: are already making plans to visit the collection.

166.53.text: additional materials relating to his life and work.

3069.57.text: Because here's something else that's true. In the day-to-day trenches

3073.70.text: of adult life, there is actually no such thing as atheism.

3077.37.text: There is no such thing as not worshipping. Everybody worships.

3085.30.text: And an outstanding reason for choosing some sort of God or spiritual-type

3089.50.text: thing to worship is that pretty much anything else you worship will eat you alive.

3094.57.text: If you worship money and things then you will never feel you have enough.

3101.83.text: you will always feel ugly, and when time and age start showing,

3112.90.text: need ever more power over others to keep the fear at bay.

3119.90.text: a fraud, always on the verge of being found out. And so on.

3123.90.text: Look, the insidious thing about these forms of worship is not that

3127.03.text: they're evil or sinful; it is that they are unconscious.

3132.90.text: They're the kind of worship you just gradually slip into,

3135.63.text: day after day, getting more and more selective about what you see and

3139.77.text: how you measure value without ever being fully aware that that's what you're doing.

3144.10.text: And the world will not discourage you from operating on your default-settings,

3149.23.text: because the world of men and money and power hums along quite nicely on the

3153.30.text: fuel of fear and contempt and frustration and craving and the worship of self.

3178.50.text: and the kind that is most precious you will not hear

3180.90.text: much talked about in the great outside world of winning and achieving and displaying.

3186.83.text: The really important kind of freedom involves attention, and awareness,

3193.83.text: and discipline, and effort, and being able truly to care about other people and to

3199.43.text: sacrifice for them, over and over, in myriad petty little unsexy ways,

3206.37.text: every day. That is real freedom.

3209.90.text: The alternative is unconsciousness, the default-setting,

3212.90.text: the "rat race" -- the constant gnawing sense of having had and lost some infinite thing.

3222.10.text: I know that this stuff probably doesn't sound fun and breezy or grandly inspirational.

3226.77.text: But please don't dismiss it as some finger-wagging Dr. Laura sermon.

3232.03.text: None of this is about morality, or religion, or dogma,

3235.70.text: or big fancy questions of life after death.

3238.83.text: The capital-T Truth is about life before death.

3244.97.text: It is about making it to 30, or maybe 50, without wanting to shoot yourself in the head.

3252.77.text: It is about simple awareness -- awareness of what is so real and essential,

3257.63.text: so hidden in plain sight all around us,

3260.63.text: that we have to keep reminding ourselves, over and over: "This is water, this is water."

3271.10.text: It is unimaginably hard to do this, to stay conscious and alive, day in and day out.
